ORDER  signed by Magistrate Judge Kendall J. Newman on 4/29/22    ORDERING that    the City's request to include a 3-bin limit for personal property is DENIED   (but personal property may be limited as set forth in the settlement  agreement).  T he City's request to institute a curfew from 11:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. is   DENIED.  However, the City may institute expanded quiet hours between 10:00   p.m. and 7:00 a.m.  The City's request to conduct warrant checks is GRANTED IN PART.   T he City's request to include a rule allowing for the expulsion from the  Campus  of an occupant solely for acts that occur outside of the Campus is   DENIED without prejudice.   The City's request to include a rule requiring dogs to be muzz led while on the   Campus and outside of the occupant's unit is GRANTED.  The City's request to limit one dog at a time in the pet run is DENIED without   prejudice, subject to the parties conferring on how to make best use  of the dog  run(s).  The parties agree on the terms of the current bag search and amnesty box   provisions on a temporary basis, and so the City's request regarding these   rules is GRANTED.   (Kaminski, H)

case_data.name: Warren v. City of Chico
case_data.plaintiff_description: Involuntarily unhoused residents of Chico, California, who are at immediate risk of being cited, arrested, and prosecuted for sleeping, sitting, lying, and resting in the City of Chico.
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
case_data.summary:
Involuntarily unhoused residents of Chico, California, filed this lawsuit against the City of Chico and the City of Chico Police Department, challenging the City’s ordinances that criminalized homelessness by banning camping and storing personal property in public places. Represented by attorneys from Legal Services of Northern California, on April 8, 2021, eight individuals sued under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and alleged violations of their rights guaranteed by the Fourth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments in the United States Constitution. The plaintiffs brought suit in the Eastern District of California. The plaintiffs sought declaratory relief and injunctive relief enjoining the City of Chico from enforcing ordinances that punished people for camping on public property when there was no alternative shelter available, and also enjoining the City from destroying the property of unhoused people. The case was initially assigned to Judge Kimberly J. Mueller, but she recused herself, and it was reassigned to Senior Judge Morrison C. England, Jr.; in 2024, it was reassigned to Judge Dale A. Drozd.


The plaintiffs alleged that due to a lack of alternative shelter for unhoused people in Chico, 66% of Chico’s homeless population was unsheltered. The plaintiffs further argued that, because Chico did not have available alternative shelter for unhoused people, the city ordinances that criminalized camping in public violated their constitutional rights. According to the complaint, the Chico ordinances criminalized homelessness by making it unlawful to (1) camp on any public property or private property that was not a designated campground; (2) store private property on parks, streets, public parking lots, or near waterways; (3) sit on sidewalks in commercial districts; (4) obstruct entrances to buildings; and (5) obstruct sidewalk traffic. The plaintiffs alleged that the Chico police enforced the ordinancesse by warning unhoused residents to move and threatening arrest if they refused to move. They further alleged that between 2018 and 2020, Chico police made 120 arrests for violations of the anti-camping ordinance. 


The plaintiffs argued that the ordinance that criminalized camping in public violated their Eighth Amendment rights under the U.S. Constitution by punishing them for life-sustaining activities such as sleeping in public, and also violated their right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment under the California Constitution. They also argued that the defendants’ practice of forcibly removing plaintiffs from encampments and forcing them to sleep on rights-of-way with only a sleeping bag was a “state-created danger” that violated the California Constitution and the Fourteenth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution. They further contended that the defendants’ seizure of property was unlawful under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments. They also argued that the anti-camping ordinances violated the plaintiffs’ due process rights under the California Constitution and the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution because the City failed to inform the public about what speech or conduct would subject them to criminal penalties. 

On April 8, 2021, the plaintiffs filed ex parte motions to proceed in forma pauperis (“IFP”; i.e., an indigent status that would allow the court to waive their costs and fees). On April 10, 2021, the plaintiffs filed an ex parte motion for a temporary restraining order with an accompanying memorandum supporting it. On April 11, 2021, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint. Whereas the initial complaint sought only injunctive relief, the amended complaint also sought declaratory relief in which the court declared that their rights had been violated. That same day, the court granted the temporary restraining order in favor of the plaintiffs. The temporary restraining order prohibited the City of Chico and its police department from enforcing notifications that gave unhoused community members at Comance Green Way 72 hours to remove their belongings and leave the location, and from issuing or enforcing similar notifications. The temporary restraining order also barred the defendants from enforcing or threatening to enforce specific municipal ordinances, including the bans on camping and storing personal property in public. It also prohibited the defendants from destroying the personal property of unhoused individuals. 

The court granted the plaintiffs’ motions to proceed IFP on April 15, 2021. On April 23, 2021, the court held a hearing on the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, which was continued to May 14, 2021. The court ordered the temporary restraining order to remain in effect until May 14. On May 10, Judge England continued the preliminary injunction hearing until June. In June, the preliminary injunction hearing was continued again, and the temporary restraining order remained in effect. 

On July 2, 2021, the court heard arguments on the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction. The court agreed to extend the temporary restraining order until it determined the outcome of the preliminary injunction motion. During these proceedings, the parties agreed to have the case referred to a magistrate judge for a settlement conference, and the case was referred to Magistrate Judge Kendall J. Newman. 


On July 8, 2021, Judge England granted the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, converting the temporary restraining order into a preliminary injunction on the same terms. In granting the preliminary injunction, Judge England concluded that the plaintiffs had shown a likelihood of success on the merits under 9th Circuit precedent, Martin v. City of Boise, 920 F.3d 584, (9th Cir. 2024), which held that under the Eighth Amendment, a jurisdiction could not prosecute homeless people for involuntary sitting, lying, or sleeping in public when there were more homeless individuals than shelter beds available in the area. 

Beginning in August 2021, the court held multiple settlement conferences throughout the remainder of the calendar year. In January 2022, the parties reached a settlement agreement and filed a proposed order for dismissal, which Judge England signed the following day, dismissing the entire action with prejudice. Chico residents sent letters and emails to the court asking Judge England to refuse to sign the current settlement agreement, which they argued was overly generous to the homeless community and burdened taxpayers. Under the terms of the settlement agreement, the City was required to construct the Chico Emergency Non-Congregate Housing Site (“Housing Site”) with at least 50 pallet shelters, personal hygiene facilities, and potable drinking water and meal services. The City also agreed not to enforce its anti-camping bans and not to require a homeless person to relocate their property until the Housing Site was open and available as alternative housing. When the Housing Site was open, the City agreed that it would require a homeless person to relocate their property or themselves only if it had assessed that there was available alternative shelter and it had given prior notice to the individual. The City also agreed that it would dismiss all administrative and criminal citations and charges against the plaintiffs related to their status as homeless. The City agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $12,000 in damages and to pay plaintiffs’ counsel $650,000 in attorneys’ fees and costs. Magistrate Judge Kendall J. Newman would oversee the implementation and enforcement of the settlement agreement for a period of five years from its effective date. 

The City opened the Housing Site in 2022, and by the end of April of that year, Magistrate Judge Newman declared that the city could begin to enforce the ordinances following the terms provided in the settlement agreement, as noted above. On August 25, 2022, the plaintiffs filed a motion to enforce the settlement agreement. On February 24, 2023, Magistrate Judge Newman issued an order after an informal conference, declaring that the City must offer three alternative sites to unhoused individuals when enforcing its ordinances and that when a homeless person goes to one of those alternative sites, the City was not allowed to enforce against that person again for at least 60 days. 

On February 5, 2024, this action was reassigned to Chief Magistrate Judge Carolyn K. Delaney, in light of Magistrate Judge Newman’s upcoming retirement. 

On June 28, 2024, the Supreme Court of the United States announced its decision in Johnson v. City of Grants Pass, Oregon, 144 S.Ct. 2022 (2024), which held that enforcing bans on sleeping or camping on public property was not prohibited “cruel and unusual punishment” under the Eighth Amendment. In light of the Grants Pass decision, the City of Chico filed a motion for relief from the injunction on August 31, 2024. In their reply brief, the plaintiffs argued that by filing the motion for relief from final judgment, the defendants were engaging in an improper attempt to circumvent the dispute resolution process that they had agreed to in the settlement agreement, which required the parties to meet informally and attend a conference with the magistrate judge before attempting to modify the settlement agreement. 

On September 6, 2024, this action was randomly reassigned to District Judge A. Drozd, and as of that date, District Judge Morrison C. England, Jr., was no longer associated with this case. 

As of December 4, 2024, the City of Chico’s motion for relief from the preliminary injunction was pending before Judge Drozd.

The complaint alleged that due to insufficient shelter space in Chico, unhoused residents were forced to sleep outside. They argued that Chicoโs ordinances that criminalized doing so violated their rights under the Fourth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution. The plaintiffs sought declaratory relief and injunctive relief enjoining the City of Chico from enforcing these ordinances and from destroying the property of unhoused people. The court granted a temporary restraining order, which was then converted into a preliminary injunction. The parties reached a settlement agreement on January 22, 2022, which required the City to open a new housing site to provide alternative shelter to its unhoused residents before it could continue to enforce or threaten to force its bans on camping and storing personal property in public places. In light of the Supreme Courtโs 2024 decision in Johnson v. City of Grants Pass, Oregon, 144 S.Ct. 2022 (2024), which held that enforcing bans on sleeping or camping on public property was not prohibited โcruel and unusual punishmentโ under the Eighth Amendment, the City of Chico filed a motion for relief from the preliminary injunction; as of December 4, 2024, that motion is pending before the court.

23  to the dispute resolution procedures outlined in the settlement agreement.  (Doc. No. 153 at 4.)  
24  On August 31, 2024, defendants filed a motion for relief from final judgment seeking โlimited 
25  relief that would allow all City pre-enforcement and enforcement of Anti-Camping Ordinances 
26  and Regulations in accordance with local, state, and federal laws, including the Grants Pass

Case 2:21-cv-00640-DAD-DMC   Document 223   Filed 11/15/24   Page 2 of 3
1  decision.โ  (Doc. No. 209 at 13.)2  In their opposition, plaintiffs argue that by filing a motion for 
2  relief from final judgment, defendants are attempting to improperly bypass the dispute resolution 
3  process outlined in the settlement agreement, which requires the parties to meet and confer 
4  informally and then attend a conference with a magistrate judge before filing a motion to modify 
5  the settlement.  (Doc. No. 216 at 11โ12.)  In their reply, defendants stated that they โrespectfully 
6  request[] that this [c]ourt provide relief from, inter alia, the dispute resolution procedures . . . .โ  
7  (Doc. No. 218 at 17.)  Plaintiffs subsequently filed the pending motion for leave to file a sur-reply 
8  to address defendantsโ request for relief from the dispute resolution process.  (Doc. No. 220 at 2.) 
9    Parties do not have a general right to file sur-reply briefs.  See L.R. 230.  However, 
10  โnothing in the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure prevents the court from granting a party leave to 
11  file a sur-reply.โ  McGechie v. Atomos Ltd., No. 2:22-cv-01812-DJC-DB, 2023 WL 2918681 at 
12  *1 (E.D. Cal. Apr. 12, 2023).  โA decision to grant or deny leave to file a sur-reply is generally 
13  committed to the sound discretion of the court.โ  Tounget v. Valley-Wide Recreation & Park 
14  Dist., No. 16-cv-00088-JGB-KK, 2020 WL 8410456 at *2 (C.D. Cal. Feb. 20, 2020) (internal 
15  quotation and citation omitted).  โAlthough the [c]ourt may in its discretion permit the filing of a 
16  sur[-]reply, this discretion should be exercised in favor of allowing a sur[-]reply only where a 
17  valid reason for such additional briefing exists, such as where the movant raises new arguments in 
18  its reply brief.โ  Fedrick v. Mercedes-Benz USA, LLC, 366 F. Supp. 2d 1190, 1197 (N.D. Ga. 
19  2005).   
20    In their motion for leave to file a sur-reply, plaintiffs contend that defendantsโ request for 
21  relief from the dispute resolution process as set forth in their reply brief โclarif[ied] the relief 
22  soughtโ and that plaintiffs โshould have an opportunity to respondโ to that new argument.  (Doc. 
23  No. 220 at 2.)  In defendantsโ opposition to plaintiffsโ motion for leave to file a sur-reply, 
24  defendants argue that, because their original motion for relief from judgment seeks relief from 
25  โcumbersome notice and enforcement proceduresโ in the settlement agreement, this implicitly 
26 
 
27  2  On September 6, 2024, this case was reassigned to the undersigned.  (Doc. Nos. 210, 211.)  On 
September 10, 2024, defendants re-noticed their motion for relief from final judgment in front of 
28  the undersigned.  (Doc. No. 213.) 
  2   
 
 
 

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-DAD-DMC   Document 223   Filed 11/15/24   Page 3 of 3
1  also seeks relief from the dispute resolution process, including relief from the required processes 
2  prior to the filing of any motion for relief from final judgment.  (Doc. No. 222 at 3โ4.)  The court 
3  has reviewed defendantsโ motion for relief from judgment and observes that the โcumbersome 
4  notice and enforcement proceduresโ that defendants refer to solely regard substantive portions of 
5  the settlement agreement, such as the processes of noticing specific encampment sites to be 
6  cleared, counting the occupants, assessing willingness to enter a shelter, etc.  (Doc. No. 213 at 
7  14.)  Accordingly, the court is not persuaded that defendantsโ motion for relief from judgment 
8  sufficiently notified plaintiffs that defendants are also seeking relief from the dispute resolution 
9  process outlined in the partiesโ settlement agreement.  Thus finds that plaintiffs have stated good 
10  cause for the filing of a sur-reply.  And their motion for leave to file a sur-reply will be granted. 
11    Also in their opposition to plaintiffsโ motion for leave to file a sur-reply, defendants 
12  request that, should the court grant plaintiffsโ request, the court also grant defendants โpermission 
13  to file a reply to the sur-reply.โ  (Doc. No. 222 at 5.)  However, granting this request at this point 
14  would encourage โan endless volley of briefs.โ  Garrison v. Ne. Ga. Med. Ctr., 66 F. Supp. 2d 
15  1336, 1340 (N.D. Ga. 1999).  Therefore, the court will deny defendantsโ request to file a reply to 
16  the sur-reply without prejudice to renewal if appropriate. 
17    Accordingly, 
18    1.  Plaintiffsโ motion for leave to file a sur-reply (Doc. No. 220) is granted;  
19  2.  The hearing on the pending motion set for November 19, 2024 in this matter is 
20  hereby vacated; and 
21  3.  Within fourteen (14) days of the date of entry of this order, plaintiffs shall file a 
22  sur-reply to defendantsโ reply in support of their motion for relief from final 
23  judgment (Doc. No. 218).  Plaintiffsโ sur-reply may only address new arguments 
24  raised for the first time in defendantsโ reply. 
 
25 
IT IS SO ORDERED. 
 
26

documents.text:
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 110   Filed 07/08/21   Page 1 of 7
1   
2   
3   
4   
5   
6   
7   
8  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
9  EASTERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
10 
11  BOBBY WARREN, et al.,  No.  2:21-CV-00640-MCE-DMC 
12  Plaintiffs,   
13  v.  MEMORANDUM AND ORDER 
14  CITY OF CHICO, et al., 
15  Defendants. 
16   
17  By way of this action, Plaintiffs Bobby Warren, Andy Lambach, Jonathon Williams, 
18  Michael Samuelson, Tracy Miller, Tona Petersen, Carol Beth Thompson, and Christa 
19  Stevens (collectively โPlaintiffsโ), who are homeless individuals, seek injunctive and 
20  declaratory relief preventing Defendants, the City of Chico (โCityโ) and the City of Chico 
21  Police Department (โPoliceโ), (collectively โDefendantsโ) from enforcing various 
22  ordinances that purportedly prevent them from โsleeping, sitting, lying, resting and simply 
23  existing in the City of Chico.โ  Pls.โ First Amended Compl. (โFACโ), ECF No. 34, ยถ 7.  
24  They also seek to enjoin the unconstitutional destruction of their personal property.  At 
25  11:39 p.m. on Saturday, April 10, 2021, Plaintiffs filed a Motion for Temporary 
26  Restraining Order (โTROโ).  ECF No. 10.  This case was assigned to this Court the 
27  following day.  Given that Plaintiffs were challenging enforcement actions set to begin 
28  the following morning, this Court issued a TRO to preserve the status quo until full 
  1   
 
 
 

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 110   Filed 07/08/21   Page 2 of 7
1  briefing could be provided and a hearing could be had on whether a longer term 
2  preliminary injunction should issue.  Essentially, the Court called a โtime-outโ prohibiting 
3  Defendants from taking any further action until it could receive briefing from both sides 
4  on the issues raised.  In keeping with the short-term nature of that TRO, the Court set a 
5  hearing on Plaintiffsโ Motion for Preliminary Injunction on April 23, 2021.  At that hearing, 
6  the parties agreed to extend the TRO so they could try to work together to reach an 
7  informal resolution of Plaintiffsโ claims.  They were not able to reach an agreement, and 
8  this case came before the Court for hearing on the pending Motion on July 2, 2021.  
9  Having considered the record in its entirety and the applicable law, Plaintiffsโ Motion is 
10  hereby GRANTED.   
11   
12 
STANDARD 
13   
14  โA preliminary injunction is an extraordinary and drastic remedy.โ  Munaf v. Geren, 
15  553 U.S. 674, 689 (2008) (internal quotation marks and citations omitted).  โ[T]he 
16  purpose of a preliminary injunction is to preserve the status quo between the parties 
17  pending a resolution of a case on the merits.โ  McCormack v. Hiedeman, 694 F.3d 1004, 
18  1019 (9th Cir. 2012).  A plaintiff seeking a preliminary injunction must establish 
19  that:  (1) he is โlikely to succeed on the merits;โ (2) he is โlikely to suffer irreparable harm 
20  in the absence of preliminary relief;โ (3) โthe balance of equities tips in his favor;โ and 
21  (4) โan injunction is in the public interest.โ  Winter v. Nat. Res. Def. Council, 555 U.S. 7, 
22  20 (2008).  โWhen the government is a partyโ to a case in which a preliminary injunction 
23  is sought, the balance of the equities and public interest factors โmerge.โ  Drakes Bay 
24  Oyster Co. v. Jewell, 747 F.3d 1073, 1092 (9th Cir. 2014).  โGenerally, public interest 
25  concerns are implicated when a constitutional right has been violated, because all 
26  citizens have a stake in upholding the constitution.โ  Preminger v. Principi, 422 F.3d 815, 
27  826 (9th Cir. 2005).  There is generally no public interest in the perpetuation of an 
28  unlawful government action.  UFW v. U.S. DOL, No. 1:20-CV-1690, 2020 WL 7646406, 
  2   
 
 
 

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 110   Filed 07/08/21   Page 3 of 7
1  at *20 (E.D. Cal. Dec. 23, 2020) (citing League of Women Voters v. Newby, 838 F.3d 1, 
2  12 (D.C. Cir. 2016)). 
3  Alternatively, under the so-called sliding scale approach, โ[t]he Ninth Circuit 
4  weighs [the above] factors on a sliding scale,โ so that where there are โโserious 
5  questions going to the meritsโโthat is, less than a โlikelihood of successโ on the meritsโ
6  a preliminary injunction may still be issued so long as โthe balance of hardships tips 
7  sharply in the plaintiffโs favorโ and the other two factors are satisfied.โ  Short v. Brown, 
8  893 F.3d 671, 675 (9th Cir. 2018) (quoting Alliance for the Wild Rockies v. Cottrell, 
9  632 F.3d 1127, 1135 (9th Cir. 2011)). 
10  โIn each case, courts โmust balance the competing claims of injury and must 
11  consider the effect on each party of the granting or withholding of the requested 
12  relief.โโ  Winter, 555 U.S. at 24 (quoting Amoco Prod. Co. v. Vill. of Gambell, 480 U.S. 
13  531, 542 (1987)).  A district court should enter a preliminary injunction only โupon a clear 
14  showing that the plaintiff is entitled to such relief.โ  Id. at 22.   
15   
16  ANALYSIS1 
17   
18  The City of Chico has put into place ordinances that make it unlawful for any 
19  individual to sit, lie, stand, sleep on any public property within the City without being 
20  subject to criminal penalties.  More specifically, Chicoโs anti-camping ordinance makes it 
21  unlawful โfor any person to camp or occupy camp facilities on any public property or any 
22  private property which is not operated and maintained as a campground . . . .โ  Chico 
23  Cal., Mun. Code ยง 9.20.030 (2021) (emphasis added).  โโCampโ means to place, pitch or 
24   
1 This Memorandum focuses on Plaintiffsโ Eighth Amendment cause of action.  It appears to the 
25 
Court that the property destruction challenged in the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment claims occurs in 
connection with cleaning up โillegalโ encampments.  That property destruction should thus cease with the 
26 
criminal enforcement of the relevant ordinances.  In an abundance of caution, however, the Court makes 
clear that it finds Plaintiffs have shown they are likely to succeed on the merits of those claims, Lavan v. 
27 
City of Los Angeles, 693 F.3d 1022, 1030 (9th Cir. 2012), they are likely to suffer imminent irreparable 
harm absent an injunction, and that the balance of equities and public interest favor issuing an injunction 
28 
as well.    
  3   
 
 
 

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 110   Filed 07/08/21   Page 4 of 7
1  occupy camp facilities; to live temporarily in a camp facility or outdoors.โ  Id. 
2  ยง 9.20.020(A) (emphasis added).  โViolation of this chapter shall be a misdemeanor or 
3  an infraction and may be enforced by the filing of a criminal action by the city attorney or 
4  the issuance of an administrative citation . . . . .โ  Id. ยง 9.20.060.  Defendantsโ counsel 
5  conceded that โa person could never sit, sleep, lie on any property or else they would . . . 
6  be criminally prosecuted . . . unless the person walked 24 hours a day and had no 
7  personal property.โ  Transcript, Apr. 23, 2021, ECF No. 72, at 19.    
8  Because the ordinances passed by the City Council subject individuals to criminal 
9  penalties for โliving outdoorsโ anywhere in the City, the result is that homeless individuals 
10  are subject to criminal prosecution no matter where they go within the jurisdiction.  This 
11  Circuit has previously held that ordinances such as this are not enforceable, unless there 
12  is enough practically available shelter within the City for all unhoused individuals.  
13  Martin v. City of Boise, 920 F.3d 584, 617 (2019) (holding โthat โso long as there is a 
14  greater number of homeless individuals in [a jurisdiction] than the number of available 
15  beds [in shelters],โ the jurisdiction cannot prosecute homeless individuals for 
16  โinvoluntarily sitting, lying, and sleeping in public.โโ) (quoting Jones v. City of Los 
17  Angeles, 444 F.3d 1118, 1138 (9th Cir. 2006)).   
18  At the first preliminary injunction hearing, Plaintiffs advised the Court there were a 
19  total of 120 shelter beds in Chico to serve an estimated homeless population of over 500 
20  individuals.  That is insufficient under Martin if Chico wants to criminalize resting on 
21  public property.  See id.2   
22  As indicated above, however, the Court extended the TRO after that initial hearing 
23  to allow the parties time to try to work toward a negotiated resolution.  According to the 
24  City, it then โconstructed an outdoor temporary shelter facility at the Chico Municipal  
25  /// 
 
26 
2 Given the great disparity between the number of beds and the number of unhoused persons, the 
Court need not get into the weeds of whether the existing beds are โpractically available.โ  There was 
27 
simply not enough shelter available for the community to opt to enforce its criminal sanctions.  Plaintiffs 
are nonetheless again advised that the Court is not necessarily convinced that the reasons they offer for 
28 
declining shelter render that shelter โpractically unavailableโ under Martin. 
  4   
 
 
 

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 110   Filed 07/08/21   Page 5 of 7
1  Airport that accommodates all 571 of the Cityโs homeless persons.โ  Defs.โ Suppl. Br., 
2  ECF No. 90, at 3:13-14.  This raises the question, โWhat is shelter?โ 
3  According to Defendants, โ[a] shelter is a practically-available space for persons 
4  who are unhoused to go on a given day that would enable a city . . . to enforce its anti-
5  camping, sit/lie, and so forth ordinances.โ  Transcript July 2, 2021, ECF No. 106, at 5:18-
6  22.  That definition does not pass the straight face test.  Calling a plot of land a shelter 
7  does not make it so.3   
8  So we turn to the dictionaries.  Merriam-Webster defines shelter as:  
9  1:  a:  something that covers or affords protection  
10  //a bomb shelter 
11    b:  an establishment providing food and shelter (as to 
the homeless) 
12 
  c:  an establishment that houses and feeds stray or 
13  unwanted animals 
14  2:   a position or the state of being covered and protected 
15  //took shelter 
16  Shelter, Mirriam-Webster, https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/shelter (last 
17  visited July 8, 2021).  In the Cambridge English dictionary, shelter is โ(a building 
18  designed to give) protection from bad weather, danger, or attack.โ  Shelter, Cambridge 
19  Dictionary, https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/shelter (last visited July 8, 
20  2021).  And Blackโs Law Dictionary defines โshelterโ as โ[a] place of refuge providing 
21  safety from danger, attack, or observation.โ  Shelter, Blackโs Law Dictionary (11th ed. 
22  2019).       
23  /// 
24   
3 To the extent Defendants instead tried to argue at the July 2 hearing that the airport site is a 
25 
designated place individuals can rest within the city limits, that argument also fails.  If Defendants want to 
exempt particular โspacesโ from criminal enforcement, they need to codify those spaces into their rules, 
26 
paying particular attention to what Martin may require.  It is unlikely that designating an airport tarmac as 
the one place in the city where individuals may rest without being criminally prosecuted would be a viable 
27 
argument under Martin.  Regardless, Chico defines โcamp facilitiesโ to include โtemporary shelters,โ Cal. 
Mun. Code ยง 9.20.020(B), which seems to mean that it is still illegal for individuals to frequent the airport 
28 
site, regardless of whether the City invites them.     
  5   
 
 
 

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 110   Filed 07/08/21   Page 6 of 7
1    Even Martin, which does not directly answer this question, seems to contemplate 
2  shelter will offer individuals a place to sleep โindoors.โ  920 F.3d at 617.    
3  Under none of these definitions is the airport site a โshelter.โ  It is an asphalt 
4  tarmac with no roof and no walls, no water and no electricity.  It is an open space with 
5  what amounts to a large umbrella for some shade.  It affords no real cover or protection 
6  to anyone.   
7  That ends the Courtโs current inquiry.  Since Chicoโs ordinances prohibit 
8  homeless persons from resting on all public property and there is not enough practically-
9  available shelter within the City, Plaintiffs have shown a likelihood of success under 
10  Martin, such that the City cannot resort to arresting people or imposing criminal penalties 
11  like fines on homeless persons in violation.4     
12  Given the likelihood of success on the merits, Plaintiffs have also shown a 
13  likelihood of irreparable harm in the form of the potential violation of their constitutional 
14  rights.  The Cityโs interest in enforcing its health and safety ordinances is not strong 
15  enough to outweigh Plaintiffs interests when balancing the equities and, given the strong 
16  showing that Plaintiffs made on the likelihood of success and irreparable harm, the 
17  public interest also tips in their favor.  Nothing in this Courtโs decision prevents the 
18  enforcement of laws that do not criminalize the status of being homeless โ e.g., public 
19  intoxication laws, destruction of public property, etc.  As such preliminary injunctive relief 
20  is appropriate.   
21  /// 
 
22 
4 As straight-forward as the Martin analysis plays out in application of the law to the facts of this 
23  case, the Court understands the practical ramifications for the community are much more complex.  
Indeed, the concerns raised in the dissent from the denial of rehearing en banc appear to have come to 
fruition in Chico.  See id. 920 F.3d at 594 (โSuch a holding leaves cities with a Hobsonโs choice: They must 
24 
either undertake an overwhelming financial responsibility to provide housing for or count the number of 
homeless individuals within their jurisdiction every night, or abandon enforcement of a host of laws 
25 
regulating public health and safety.โ); id. at 596 (โI fear that the panelโs decision will prohibit local 
governments from fulfilling their duty to enforce an array of public health and safety laws.  Halting 
26 
enforcement of such laws will potentially wreak havoc on our communities.  As we have already begun to 
witness, our neighborhoods will soon feature โ[t]ents ... equipped with mini refrigerators, cupboards, 
27 
televisions, and heaters, [that] vie with pedestrian trafficโ and โhuman waste appearing on sidewalks and at 
local playgrounds.โโ) (footnotes and citations omitted).  The impact on local governments was a foregone 
28  conclusion under Martin.     
  6   
 
 
 

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 110   Filed 07/08/21   Page 7 of 7
1  CONCLUSION 
2     
3  Accordingly, for the foregoing reasons, Plaintiffsโ motion for a preliminary 
4  injunction is GRANTED.  The TRO already in place is hereby converted to a preliminary 
5  injunction on the same terms previously set forth.  This injunction shall remain in effect 
6  until a judgment is entered in this case or it is lifted by order of this Court.    
7  IT IS SO ORDERED. 
8  DATED:  July 8, 2021

1   
 
2  PRELIMINARY STATEMENT 
3  1.  Acknowledging an unprecedented shortage of emergency shelter and affordable 
4  housing, the City of Chico, located in Butte County declared a shelter crisis in October 2018. Just 
5  one month later, the Camp Fire destroyed nearly 14,000 single-family and multifamily homes in 
6  the county, leaving tens of thousands of people in the county homeless. Less than two years later, 
7  in 2020, another wildfire destroyed hundreds of homes. In 2018, when the City of Chico declared 
8  a shelter emergency, there were nearly 1,000 homeless residents in the entire county, hundreds of 
9  whom were unhoused. Today, more than two years after the Camp Fire, the Housing Authority of 
10  the County of Butte estimates that there are more than six thousand households in Chico and its 
11  neighboring town, Oroville that lack permanent housing and are sleeping in tents, cars, and camp 
12  trailers.  
13  2.  In 2020, the available shelter beds in the region decreased due to the COVID-19 
14  pandemic. The only congregate shelter in Chico reduced its capacity to reduce the spread of the 
15  virus. The cityโs temporary winter shelter did not open for most of the winter. At the same time, 
16  there is a zero percent rental housing vacancy rate and rents have increased to unaffordable levels 
17  for Chicoโs lowest income residents.  
18  3.  In December 2020, fully aware of the housing crisis and hundreds, if not thousands 
19  of unhoused community members without access to indoor shelter, the Chico City Council 
20  adopted an ordinance criminalizing camping and remaining after-hours in city parks and open 
21  spaces. The ordinance increased penalties for these acts from administrative citations to criminal 
22  penalties, which permitted the City to arrest and charge unhoused community members with 
23  misdemeanors for resting or sleeping in areas of the city where they were least likely to obstruct 
24  traffic, disturb commercial activity or increase risk of community spread of COVID-19. 
25  4.  In January 2021, the City and Police Department began aggressive enforcement of 
26  the new ordinance and an older citywide ordinance that bans camping on any public property 
27  within city limits. Law enforcement has methodically, location by location, forced unhoused 
28  residents to leave their resting and sleeping places by threatening criminal citation, arrest, and 
  2   
First Amended Complaint (Warren, et al v. Chico)  
  

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 34   Filed 04/11/21   Page 3 of 33
 
 
 
1  seizure of the residentsโ property.   
 
2  5.  These two anti-camping ordinances are part of a larger scheme of local laws that 
3  impose criminal penalties for homeless people when they sleep, sit, lie down, and rest in public. 
4  The city continued enforcing this web of ordinances, even following the devastating wildfire 
5  disasters and pausing only briefly during the current COVID-19 pandemic. According to public 
6  documents, the city made 120 arrests for violations of the citywide anti-camping ordinance 
7  between 2018 and 2020. Through its recent increased enforcement that started on January 7, 
8  2021, the city has enforced its anti-camping ordinances by threatening more than 100 unsheltered 
9  people with arrest at various locations throughout the city. 
10  6.  Defendants actions against involuntarily homeless individuals violate their right to 
11  be free from cruel and unusual punishment and excessive fees, and to due process of the law 
12  under the Eight and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution. Defendants 
13  persistent and aggressive enforcement initiative is taking place as the global COVID-19 pandemic 
14  continues to pose immediate danger to the health and safety all people who are unsheltered, and 
15  to the entire community, in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment.  
16  7.  Plaintiffs are all involuntarily unhoused residents of Chico. They are at immediate 
17  risk of being cited, arrested and prosecuted for sleeping, sitting, lying, resting and simply existing 
18  in the City of Chico. Plaintiffs seek prospective injunctive and declaratory relief pursuant to 42 
19  U.S.C. section 1983.  
20  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
21  8.  This is a civil rights action arising under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 based upon the 
22  violations of Plaintiffsโ rights under the Fourth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the 
23  United States Constitution. Jurisdiction exists pursuant to 28 U.S.C. sections 1331 (federal 
24  question jurisdiction) and 1343 (civil rights jurisdiction). Jurisdiction also exists under the 
25  Declaratory Judgment Act, 28 U.S.C. ยงยง2201(a) and 2202. 
26  9.  This Court has supplemental jurisdiction over the related state law claims pursuant 
27  to 28 U.S.C. section 1367(a) because those claims form part of the same case or controversy 
28  under Article III of the United States Constitution. Plaintiffsโ state law claims share all common 
  3   
First Amended Complaint (Warren, et al v. Chico)  
  

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 34   Filed 04/11/21   Page 4 of 33
 
 
 
1  operative facts with their federal law claims, and the parties are identical. Resolving Plaintiffโs 
 
2  federal and state claims in a single action serves the interests of judicial economy, convenience, 
3  consistency, and fairness to the parties. 
4  10.  Venue is proper in the Sacramento Division of the Eastern District in that the 
5  events and conduct complained of herein all occurred in the City of Chico, located in Butte 
6  County. 
7  PARTIES 
8  11.  Plaintiff Bobby Warren is and was at all relevant times an involuntarily unhoused 
9  resident of Chico, California. 
10  12.  Plaintiff Andy Lambach is and was at all relevant times an involuntarily unhoused 
11  resident of Chico, California.

17  resident of Chico, California.

19  resident of Chico, California.

21  unhoused resident of Chico, California.

23  resident of Chico, California. 
24  19.  Defendant City of Chico is a government entity with the capacity to sue and be 
25  sued. Employees of the City of Chico have engaged in the acts complained of herein pursuant to 
26  the official policies, practices and customs of the City of Chico that are consented to and 
27  authorized by policymakers of the City of Chico. The acts complained of were intentionally 
28  committed, are ongoing, and will continued unless restrained by the Court.  
  4   
First Amended Complaint (Warren, et al v. Chico)  
  

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 34   Filed 04/11/21   Page 5 of 33
 
 
 
1  20.  Defendant City of Chico Police Department is a department of the City of Chico. 
 
2  The Police Department employees enforce the actions, policies, procedures, practices, and 
3  customs of both the City of Chico and City of Chico Police Department policy makers.  
4  FACTS 
5  CHICOโS LACK OF ADEQUATE SHELTER 
6  21.  The City of Chico has had an affordable housing crisis that has persisted for 
7  several years. On October 2, 2018, the city declared a shelter crisis based on a finding that a 
8  significant number of persons located within the City are unable to find shelter. 
9  22.  The 2019 Point-in-Time Survey of people who are homeless in Butte County 
10  reaffirmed the continuation of this crisis. The 2019 Point-in-Time Survey, which is the most 
11  recent survey completed, found that there were 891 unsheltered, 420 sheltered, and 993 people 
12  sheltered with Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) support in Butte County. About 
13  43.66 percent of those unsheltered in Butte County live in the City of Chico.  
14  23.  According to the 2019 Point-In-Time Survey, in Chico alone, there are 571 
15  unsheltered individuals and 293 sheltered individuals, meaning 66 percent of Chicoโs homeless 
16  population is unsheltered. The report estimated that the actual number is higher, โdue to ongoing 
17  challenges in locating homeless individuals, especially those who are displaced and unhoused due 
18  to the Camp Fire.โ 
19  24.  The number of unhoused individuals and families in Butte County increased 
20  dramatically after the 2018 Camp Fire and the 2020 North Complex Fires. The Housing Authority 
21  of the County of Butte estimates that today as many as six to seven thousand households in 
22  Chico, and its neighboring town, Oroville are unhoused and living in tents or trailers. The 
23  Housing Authority also estimates that within these unhoused households there are 500 school-
24  aged children.  
25  25.  The 2019 Point-in-Time Survey found that 31 percent of all people experiencing 
26  homelessness in Chico reported losing homes in the Camp Fire. Eighty percent of Camp Fire 
27  survivors experiencing homelessness in Chico are unsheltered โ 38 percent of whom report 
28  sleeping with a friend or family in their house or apartment, 30 percent on the street or sidewalk, 
  5   
First Amended Complaint (Warren, et al v. Chico)  
  

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 34   Filed 04/11/21   Page 6 of 33
 
 
 
1  14 percent in the park, 8 percent in an outdoor encampment, 5 percent under a bridge/overpass, 
 
2  and 5 percent โother.โ 
3  26.  About 69 percent of people experiencing homelessness in Chico reported in the 
4  2019 Point-in-Time Survey that they are homeless for financial reasons. 
5  27.  On February 2, 2021, a staff report directed to the Chico City Council stated, 
6  โThere is insufficient capacity to shelter everyone experiencing homelessness in Chico.โ 
7  28.  There are only two emergency shelter providers in Chico. These two shelters do 
8  not have sufficient combined capacity for all people who are unsheltered in Chico, and only have 
9  a combined maximum capacity of 130 โ 135 beds due to COVID-19 virus transmission safety 
10  protocols.  
11  29.  One of the two shelters is the Torres Community Shelter, a year-round congregate 
12  emergency shelter that is available to unsheltered men and women. It also operates a shelter in 
13  another location for families with children. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Torres Shelter 
14  currently has a reduced capacity of 120 beds.  
15  30.  Guests of the Torres Shelter sleep in a communal setting and are provided meals.  
16  The shelter has limited ability to provide accommodations for guests with disabilities or medical 
17  conditions who require a special diet, private space or service animals. For the most part, the 
18  shelter cannot accommodate pets.  
19  31.  The second shelter, Safe Space Winter Shelter, is a temporary winter shelter. 
20  However, it did not open in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. In February 2021, the shelter 
21  opened a medical referral-only shelter in rotating locations with 10 to 15 beds for unsheltered 
22  individuals, including those discharged from Enloe Hospital or Oroville Hospital or referred by 
23  Project Roomkey. The Safe Space Winter Shelter will end in mid-April 2021. The shelter is 
24  currently full and has a waitlist. It is not generally available to people who are unsheltered. 
25  32.  Project Roomkey provides hotel rooms to unhoused people who are vulnerable to 
26  complications from COVID-19, in accordance with Center for Disease Control (CDC) Guidelines 
27  to provide non-congregate sheltering wherever possible and with state and local shelter-in-place 
28  rules and recommendations. While there remain approximately 79 people in the program, Project 
  6   
First Amended Complaint (Warren, et al v. Chico)  
  

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 34   Filed 04/11/21   Page 7 of 33
 
 
 
1  Roomkey is no longer available as an emergency shelter. It is only for people who are currently 
 
2  unsheltered if they have been exposed to or contracted COVID-19. 
3  33.  The City of Chico now has fewer shelter beds than it did in 2018 when it declared 
4  a shelter crisis, despite having more people who are unsheltered.  
5  34.  When Chico declared a shelter crisis, the rental housing vacancy rate was less than 
6  2 percent. One month later, following the Camp Fire, the vacancy rate dropped to nearly zero as 
7  Chico absorbed more than 18,000 new residents between 2018 and 2020, a 20 percent population 
8  increase. During the same period, however, the city added fewer than 3,900 new housing units, an  
9  increase of only 1.4 percent.  
10  35.  The HUD Fair Market Rent for a one-bedroom unit in Chico increased from $785 
11  in 2018 to $894 in 2019 and has remained around $900. Actual median rents are higher.  
12  36.  Nearly one quarter (23.2 percent) of Chico residents live in poverty. This is more 
13  than double the poverty rate of the California, which is 11.8 percent. Butte County also has a high 
14  poverty rate of 16.1 percent.  
15  37.  Inexplicably, the city rescinded its shelter crisis declaration on April 6, 2021, 
16  despite having more people who are unhoused and fewer emergency shelter options than when it 
17  declared the crisis in 2018. The cityโs action will result in less pubic money to provide shelter and 
18  housing for unhoused community members.  
19  CHICOโS POLICY AND PRACTICE OF CRIMINALIZING HOMELESSNESS 
20  Chicoโs Laws Punishing Homelessness 
21  38.  In December 2020, the Chico City Council passed Ordinance 2556 to criminalize 
22  violations of the cityโs park regulations in Chico Municipal Code Chapter 12R.04, including 
23  camping in parks and greenways. At the December 8, 2020 Chico City Council meeting in which 
24  the city adopted Ordinance 2556, city staff and city council members said the proposed ordinance 
25  was needed to give the city the authority to criminally cite, arrest, and initiate misdemeanor 
26  charges for violations of the existing park regulations, which previously only allowed the city to 
27  administer a fine. The council passed Ordinance 2556, creating Chico Municipal Code Chapter 
28  12.18 as an urgency ordinance on December 8, 2020. The council voted to enact Ordinance 2556, 
  7   
First Amended Complaint (Warren, et al v. Chico)  
  

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 34   Filed 04/11/21   Page 8 of 33
 
 
 
1  creating Chico Municipal Code Chapter 12.18 as a regular ordinance, on December 15, 2020. 
 
2  39.  Ordinance 2557 applies to thousands of acres of public property in Chico, 
3  including all of the cityโs parks; all city-owned greenways, adjoining all creeks, streams, and 
4  watercourses; and any property purchased by or accepted by the city for use of a park or 
5  playground.  C.M.C. ยง 12.04.010 and 12.18.020(N).  
6  40.  The land subject to Ordinance 2557 represents nearly all, if not all, of the city-
7  owned public spaces that are realistically available for people who are unsheltered to 
8  involuntarily sleep and engage in other conduct that is an unavoidable consequence their 
9  unhoused status. The City of Chico spans 27.8 square miles and Bidwell Park alone spans 5.73 
10  square miles, more than a fifth of the cityโs private and public land.  
11  41.  Chico Municipal Code Chapter 12.18 states in part: 
12  12.18.430 Camping - Prohibited - Exception - Permit required. 
13  No person or group of persons shall camp overnight or remain or stay overnight within 
14  any city park or playground unlessโฆ the overnight camping or stay is authorized by a 
15  permitโฆ 
16  12.18.450 Closure of parks, greenways and open spaces.  
17  [I]t is unlawful for any person to be present in any city of Chico or Chico Area Parks and 
18  Recreation District parks, greenways, or open spaces during the hours the parks, 
19  greenways. or open spaces are closed. Unless otherwise posted, closing hours shall be 
20  between the hours of 11 :00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
21  42.  Chapter 12.18 does not define โcamp.โ 
22  43.  In addition to Ordinance 2557, the City has multiple ordinances that punish 
23  unhoused people for sleeping, sitting, lying, resting, or simply existing on public property. These 
24  ordinances are all punishable by administrative citation, infraction, or misdemeanor.  
25  44.  Citywide Camping Prohibition - Chicoโs Municipal Codes 9.20.020 and 
26  9.20.030 prohibits camping on all public property and states in part: 
27  9.20.020 Definitions. 
28  A. โCampโ means to place, pitch or occupy camp facilities; to live temporarily in a camp 
  8   
First Amended Complaint (Warren, et al v. Chico)  
  

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 34   Filed 04/11/21   Page 9 of 33
 
 
 
1  facility or outdoors 
 
2  B. โCamp facilitiesโ include, but are not limited to, tents, huts, vehicles, recreational 
3  vehicles, or temporary shelters. 
4  9.20.030 Unlawful camping. 
5  [I]t is unlawful and a public nuisance for any person to camp or occupy camp facilities on 
6  any public property or any private property which is not operated and maintained as a 
7  campgroundโฆโ 
8  45.  Storage of Personal Property in Public Places - Chico Municipal Code 9.20.050 
9  prohibits storage of personal property in public places and states: 
10  It shall be unlawful for any person to store personal property, including camp facilities 
11  and camp paraphernalia, in the following areas, except as otherwise provided by 
12  resolution of the city council: 
13  A.  Any park; 
14  B.  Any street; 
15  C.  Any public parking lot or public area, improved or unimproved; and 
16  D.  On, near or adjacent to any waterway as defined in Section 9.50.020 of this 
17  code. 
18  46.  Sitting on Sidewalks in Commercial Districts - Chico Municipal Code 9.44.015, 
19  which prohibits sitting on sidewalks in commercial districts, states in part: 
20  A. Prohibition. No person shall sit or lie down upon a public sidewalk, curb or street, or 
21  upon a blanket, stool, chair or other object placed upon a public sidewalk, curb or street 
22  which is adjacent to any property zoned or used for commercial uses, . . .โ 
23  47.  Obstructing Entrance to Buildings - Chico Municipal Code 9.44.018 states: 
24  No person shall stand, sit at or otherwise occupy the entrance of any building, including 
25  but not limited to a public or private building, church, hall, theater, place of public 
26  assemblage, store, or business so as in any manner to willfully or maliciously obstruct the 
27  entrance. 
28  48.  Congestion on Sidewalks - Chico Municipal Code 9.44.010 states: 
  9   
First Amended Complaint (Warren, et al v. Chico)  
  

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 34   Filed 04/11/21   Page 10 of 33
 
 
 
1  Except when authorized by a permit issued pursuant to Title 14 of this code, it shall be 
 
2  unlawful for any person to obstruct the free passage of traffic upon any sidewalk. 
3  49.  Civic Center Hours - Chico Municipal Code 9.43.030, states in part: 
4  B. It shall be prohibited and a violation of this section for a member of the public to 
5  access, use, be present, enter, or remain within the civic center between the hours of 10:01 
6  p.m. and 6:59 a.m. of the succeeding dayโฆ 
7  50.  Waterways - Chico Municipal Code 9.50.030, states in part:  
8  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person to engage in or 
9  maintainโฆ any of the following activities or conditions in regulated areas: 
10  B. Staying or camping overnight pursuant to Chapter 9.20 of this code. 
11  C. Store personal property pursuant to Section 9.20.050 of this code.  
12  51.  Park Regulations - The City also has park regulations, including 12R.04.340, 
13  which states in part:  
14  No person or group of persons shall camp overnight or remain or stay overnight within 
15  any city park or playground unlessโฆ the overnight camping or stay is authorized by a 
16  permitโฆ The park regulations are punishable by a fine. 
17  Chico Arrests, Cites, and Threatens to Arrest Unhoused Community Members Sleeping on 
18  Public Property 
19  52.  Between 2018 and 2020, Chico public records provided by the city to Legal 
20  Services of Northern California pursuant to a public records act request show that the Defendants 
21  made 120 arrests for violations of its citywide anti-camping ordinance, Chico Municipal Code 
22  section 9.20.030. During this same time period, the city issued 21 administrative citations for 
23  violations of section 9.20.030.  
24  53.  Chico police also have a  policy and practice of enforcing the anti-camping 
25  ordinance as well as the other ordinances that prohibit sleeping, sitting, lying, and resting on 
26  public property by warning people to move and threating citation or arrest if they refuse to move. 
27  Public records provided by the City show that between 2018 and 2020, police resolved 968 
28  citywide calls for service based on complaints of unlawful camping with the disposition

1  PRELIMINARY STATEMENT 
 
2  1.  Acknowledging an unprecedented shortage of emergency shelter and affordable 
3  housing, the City of Chico, located in Butte County declared a shelter crisis in October 2018. Just 
4  one month later, the Camp Fire destroyed nearly 14,000 single-family and multifamily homes in 
5  the county, leaving tens of thousands of people in the county homeless. Less than two years later, 
6  in 2020, another wildfire destroyed hundreds of homes. In 2018, when the City of Chico declared 
7  a shelter emergency, there were nearly 1,000 homeless residents in the entire county, hundreds of 
8  whom were unhoused. Today, more than two years after the Camp Fire, the Housing Authority of 
9  the County of Butte estimates that there are more than six thousand households in Chico and its 
10  neighboring town, Oroville that lack permanent housing and are sleeping in tents, cars, and camp 
11  trailers.  
12  2.  In 2020, the available shelter beds in the region decreased due to the COVID-19 
13  pandemic. The only congregate shelter in Chico reduced its capacity to reduce the spread of the 
14  virus. The cityโs temporary winter shelter did not open for most of the winter. At the same time, 
15  there is a zero percent rental housing vacancy rate and rents have increased to unaffordable levels 
16  for Chicoโs lowest income residents.  
17  3.  In December 2020, fully aware of the housing crisis and hundreds, if not thousands 
18  of unhoused community members without access to indoor shelter, the Chico City Council 
19  adopted an ordinance criminalizing camping and remaining after-hours in city parks and open 
20  spaces. The ordinance increased penalties for these acts from administrative citations to criminal 
21  penalties, which permitted the City to arrest and charge unhoused community members with 
22  misdemeanors for resting or sleeping in areas of the city where they were least likely to obstruct 
23  traffic, disturb commercial activity or increase risk of community spread of COVID-19. 
24  4.  In January 2021, the City began aggressive enforcement of the new ordinance and 
25  an older citywide ordinance that bans camping on any public property within city limits. Law 
26  enforcement has methodically, location by location, forced unhoused residents to leave their 
27  resting and sleeping places by threatening criminal citation, arrest, and seizure of the residentsโ 
28  property.   
  2   
Complaint (Warren, et al v. Chico)  
  

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-KJM-DMC   Document 1   Filed 04/08/21   Page 3 of 31
 
 
 
1  5.  These two anti-camping ordinances are part of a larger scheme of local laws that 
 
2  impose criminal penalties for homeless people when they sleep, sit, lie down, and rest in public. 
3  The city continued enforcing this web of ordinances, even following the devastating wildfire 
4  disasters and pausing only briefly during the current COVID-19 pandemic. According to public 
5  documents, the city made 120 arrests for violations of the citywide anti-camping ordinance 
6  between 2018 and 2020. Through its recent increased enforcement that started on January 7, 
7  2021, the city has enforced its anti-camping ordinances by threatening more than 100 unsheltered 
8  people with arrest at various locations throughout the city. 
9  6.  The cityโs actions against involuntarily homeless individuals violate their right to 
10  be free from cruel and unusual punishment and excessive fees, and to due process of the law 
11  under the Eight and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution. The cityโs 
12  persistent and aggressive enforcement initiative is taking place as the global COVID-19 pandemic 
13  continues to pose immediate danger to the health and safety all people who are unsheltered, and 
14  to the entire community, in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment.  
15  7.  Plaintiffs are all involuntarily unhoused residents of Chico. They are at immediate 
16  risk of being cited, arrested and prosecuted for sleeping, sitting, lying, resting and simply existing 
17  in the City of Chico. Plaintiffs seek prospective injunctive and declaratory relief pursuant to 42 
18  U.S.C. section 1983.  
19  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
20  8.  This is a civil rights action arising under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 based upon the 
21  violations of Plaintiffsโ rights under the Fourth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the 
22  United States Constitution. Jurisdiction exists pursuant to 28 U.S.C. sections 1331 (federal 
23  question jurisdiction) and 1343 (civil rights jurisdiction). Jurisdiction also exists under the 
24  Declaratory Judgment Act, 28 U.S.C. ยงยง2201(a) and 2202. 
25  9.  This Court has supplemental jurisdiction over the related state law claims pursuant 
26  to 28 U.S.C. section 1367(a) because those claims form part of the same case or controversy 
27  under Article III of the United States Constitution. Plaintiffsโ state law claims share all common 
28  operative facts with their federal law claims, and the parties are identical. Resolving Plaintiffโs

1  federal and state claims in a single action serves the interests of judicial economy, convenience,

3  10.  Venue is proper in the Sacramento Division of the Eastern District in that the 
4  events and conduct complained of herein all occurred in the City of Chico, located in Butte

Authority For Civil Cover Sheet
The JS 44 civil cover sheet and the information contained herein neither replaces nor supplements the filings and service of pleading or other papers as 
required by law, except as provided by local rules of court.  This form, approved by the Judicial Conference of the United States in September 1974, is 
required for the use of the Clerk of Court for the purpose of initiating the civil docket sheet.  Consequently, a civil cover sheet is submitted to the Clerk of 
Court for each civil complaint filed.  The attorney filing a case should complete the form as follows: 
I.(a)  Plaintiffs-Defendants.  Enter names (last, first, middle initial) of plaintiff and defendant.  If the plaintiff or defendant is a government agency, use   
only the full name or standard abbreviations. If the plaintiff or defendant is an official within a government agency, identify first the agency and then 
the official, giving both name and title.
   (b) County of Residence.  For each civil case filed, except U.S. plaintiff cases, enter the name of the county where the first listed plaintiff resides at the 
time of filing. In U.S. plaintiff cases, enter the name of the county in which the first listed defendant resides at the time of filing. (NOTE: In land 
condemnation cases, the county of residence of the "defendant" is the location of the tract of land involved.) 
   (c) Attorneys.  Enter the firm name, address, telephone number, and attorney of record.  If there are several attorneys, list them on an attachment, noting  
in this section "(see attachment)". 
II.    Jurisdiction.  The basis of jurisdiction is set forth under Rule 8(a), F.R.Cv.P., which requires that jurisdictions be shown in pleadings.  Place an "X" 
in one of the boxes. If there is more than one basis of jurisdiction, precedence is given in the order shown below. 
United States plaintiff.  (1) Jurisdiction based on 28 U.S.C. 1345 and 1348.  Suits by agencies and officers of the United States are included here. 
United States defendant.  (2) When the plaintiff is suing the United States, its officers or agencies, place an "X" in this box. 
Federal question.  (3) This refers to suits under 28 U.S.C. 1331, where jurisdiction arises under the Constitution of the United States, an amendment 
to the Constitution, an act of Congress or a treaty of the United States. In cases where the U.S. is a party, the U.S. plaintiff or defendant code takes 
precedence, and box 1 or 2 should be marked. 
Diversity of citizenship.  (4) This refers to suits under 28 U.S.C. 1332, where parties are citizens of different states.  When Box 4 is checked, the  
citizenship of the different parties must be checked.  (See Section III below; NOTE: federal question actions take precedence over diversity  
cases.) 
III.    Residence (citizenship) of Principal Parties.  This section of the JS 44 is to be completed if diversity of citizenship was indicated above.  Mark this 
section for each principal party. 
IV.  Nature of Suit.  Place an "X" in the appropriate box.  If there are multiple nature of suit codes associated with the case, pick the nature of suit code  
that is most applicable.  Click here for: Nature of Suit Code Descriptions. 
V.   Origin.  Place an "X" in one of the seven boxes. 
Original Proceedings.  (1) Cases which originate in the United States district courts. 
Removed from State Court.  (2) Proceedings initiated in state courts may be removed to the district courts under Title 28 U.S.C., Section 1441.   
Remanded from Appellate Court.  (3) Check this box for cases remanded to the district court for further action.  Use the date of remand as the filing 
date. 
Reinstated or Reopened.  (4) Check this box for cases reinstated or reopened in the district court.  Use the reopening date as the filing date. 
Transferred from Another District.  (5) For cases transferred under Title 28 U.S.C. Section 1404(a).  Do not use this for within district transfers or
multidistrict litigation transfers. 
Multidistrict Litigation โ Transfer.  (6) Check this box when a multidistrict case is transferred into the district under authority of Title 28 U.S.C. 
Section 1407. 
Multidistrict Litigation โ Direct File.  (8) Check this box when a multidistrict case is filed in the same district as the Master MDL docket.  
PLEASE NOTE THAT THERE IS NOT AN ORIGIN CODE 7.  Origin Code 7 was used for historical records and is no longer relevant due to  
changes in statue. 
VI.   Cause of Action.  Report the civil statute directly related to the cause of action and give a brief description of the cause.  Do not cite jurisdictional  
statutes unless diversity.  Example: U.S. Civil Statute: 47 USC 553 Brief Description: Unauthorized reception of cable service. 
VII.   Requested in Complaint.  Class Action.  Place an "X" in this box if you are filing a class action under Rule 23, F.R.Cv.P. 
Demand.  In this space enter the actual dollar amount being demanded or indicate other demand, such as a preliminary injunction. 
Jury Demand.  Check the appropriate box to indicate whether or not a jury is being demanded. 
VIII.   Related Cases.  This section of the JS 44 is used to reference related pending cases, if any.  If there are related pending cases, insert the docket  
numbers and the corresponding judge names for such cases. 
Date and Attorney Signature.  Date and sign the civil cover sheet.

2  PRELIMINARY STATEMENT 
3  1.  Acknowledging an unprecedented shortage of emergency shelter and affordable 
4  housing, the City of Chico, located in Butte County declared a shelter crisis in October 2018. Just 
5  one month later, the Camp Fire destroyed nearly 14,000 single-family and multifamily homes in 
6  the county, leaving tens of thousands of people in the county homeless. Less than two years later, 
7  in 2020, another wildfire destroyed hundreds of homes. In 2018, when the City of Chico declared 
8  a shelter emergency, there were nearly 1,000 homeless residents in the entire county, hundreds of 
9  whom were unhoused. Today, more than two years after the Camp Fire, the Housing Authority of 
10  the County of Butte estimates that there are more than six thousand households in Chico and its 
11  neighboring town, Oroville that lack permanent housing and are sleeping in tents, cars, and camp 
12  trailers.  
13  2.  In 2020, the available shelter beds in the region decreased due to the COVID-19 
14  pandemic. The only congregate shelter in Chico reduced its capacity to reduce the spread of the 
15  virus. The cityโs temporary winter shelter did not open for most of the winter. At the same time, 
16  there is a zero percent rental housing vacancy rate and rents have increased to unaffordable levels 
17  for Chicoโs lowest income residents.  
18  3.  In December 2020, fully aware of the housing crisis and hundreds, if not thousands 
19  of unhoused community members without access to indoor shelter, the Chico City Council 
20  adopted an ordinance criminalizing camping and remaining after-hours in city parks and open 
21  spaces. The ordinance increased penalties for these acts from administrative citations to criminal 
22  penalties, which permitted the City to arrest and charge unhoused community members with 
23  misdemeanors for resting or sleeping in areas of the city where they were least likely to obstruct 
24  traffic, disturb commercial activity or increase risk of community spread of COVID-19. 
25  4.  In January 2021, the City and Police Department began aggressive enforcement of 
26  the new ordinance and an older citywide ordinance that bans camping on any public property 
27  within city limits. Law enforcement has methodically, location by location, forced unhoused 
28  residents to leave their resting and sleeping places by threatening criminal citation, arrest, and 
  2   
First Amended Complaint (Warren, et al v. Chico)  
  

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 34   Filed 04/11/21   Page 3 of 33
 
 
 
1  seizure of the residentsโ property.   
 
2  5.  These two anti-camping ordinances are part of a larger scheme of local laws that 
3  impose criminal penalties for homeless people when they sleep, sit, lie down, and rest in public. 
4  The city continued enforcing this web of ordinances, even following the devastating wildfire 
5  disasters and pausing only briefly during the current COVID-19 pandemic. According to public 
6  documents, the city made 120 arrests for violations of the citywide anti-camping ordinance 
7  between 2018 and 2020. Through its recent increased enforcement that started on January 7, 
8  2021, the city has enforced its anti-camping ordinances by threatening more than 100 unsheltered 
9  people with arrest at various locations throughout the city. 
10  6.  Defendants actions against involuntarily homeless individuals violate their right to 
11  be free from cruel and unusual punishment and excessive fees, and to due process of the law 
12  under the Eight and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution. Defendants 
13  persistent and aggressive enforcement initiative is taking place as the global COVID-19 pandemic 
14  continues to pose immediate danger to the health and safety all people who are unsheltered, and 
15  to the entire community, in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment.  
16  7.  Plaintiffs are all involuntarily unhoused residents of Chico. They are at immediate 
17  risk of being cited, arrested and prosecuted for sleeping, sitting, lying, resting and simply existing 
18  in the City of Chico. Plaintiffs seek prospective injunctive and declaratory relief pursuant to 42 
19  U.S.C. section 1983.  
20  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
21  8.  This is a civil rights action arising under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 based upon the 
22  violations of Plaintiffsโ rights under the Fourth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the 
23  United States Constitution. Jurisdiction exists pursuant to 28 U.S.C. sections 1331 (federal 
24  question jurisdiction) and 1343 (civil rights jurisdiction). Jurisdiction also exists under the 
25  Declaratory Judgment Act, 28 U.S.C. ยงยง2201(a) and 2202. 
26  9.  This Court has supplemental jurisdiction over the related state law claims pursuant 
27  to 28 U.S.C. section 1367(a) because those claims form part of the same case or controversy 
28  under Article III of the United States Constitution. Plaintiffsโ state law claims share all common

1  20.  Defendant City of Chico Police Department is a department of the City of Chico. 
 
2  The Police Department employees enforce the actions, policies, procedures, practices, and 
3  customs of both the City of Chico and City of Chico Police Department policy makers.  
4  FACTS 
5  CHICOโS LACK OF ADEQUATE SHELTER 
6  21.  The City of Chico has had an affordable housing crisis that has persisted for 
7  several years. On October 2, 2018, the city declared a shelter crisis based on a finding that a 
8  significant number of persons located within the City are unable to find shelter. 
9  22.  The 2019 Point-in-Time Survey of people who are homeless in Butte County 
10  reaffirmed the continuation of this crisis. The 2019 Point-in-Time Survey, which is the most 
11  recent survey completed, found that there were 891 unsheltered, 420 sheltered, and 993 people 
12  sheltered with Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) support in Butte County. About 
13  43.66 percent of those unsheltered in Butte County live in the City of Chico.  
14  23.  According to the 2019 Point-In-Time Survey, in Chico alone, there are 571 
15  unsheltered individuals and 293 sheltered individuals, meaning 66 percent of Chicoโs homeless 
16  population is unsheltered. The report estimated that the actual number is higher, โdue to ongoing 
17  challenges in locating homeless individuals, especially those who are displaced and unhoused due 
18  to the Camp Fire.โ 
19  24.  The number of unhoused individuals and families in Butte County increased 
20  dramatically after the 2018 Camp Fire and the 2020 North Complex Fires. The Housing Authority 
21  of the County of Butte estimates that today as many as six to seven thousand households in 
22  Chico, and its neighboring town, Oroville are unhoused and living in tents or trailers. The 
23  Housing Authority also estimates that within these unhoused households there are 500 school-
24  aged children.  
25  25.  The 2019 Point-in-Time Survey found that 31 percent of all people experiencing 
26  homelessness in Chico reported losing homes in the Camp Fire. Eighty percent of Camp Fire 
27  survivors experiencing homelessness in Chico are unsheltered โ 38 percent of whom report 
28  sleeping with a friend or family in their house or apartment, 30 percent on the street or sidewalk, 
  5   
First Amended Complaint (Warren, et al v. Chico)  
  

 
Case 2:21-cv-00640-MCE-DMC   Document 34   Filed 04/11/21   Page 6 of 33
 
 
 
1  14 percent in the park, 8 percent in an outdoor encampment, 5 percent under a bridge/overpass, 
 
2  and 5 percent โother.โ 
3  26.  About 69 percent of people experiencing homelessness in Chico reported in the 
4  2019 Point-in-Time Survey that they are homeless for financial reasons. 
5  27.  On February 2, 2021, a staff report directed to the Chico City Council stated, 
6  โThere is insufficient capacity to shelter everyone experiencing homelessness in Chico.โ 
7  28.  There are only two emergency shelter providers in Chico. These two shelters do 
8  not have sufficient combined capacity for all people who are unsheltered in Chico, and only have 
9  a combined maximum capacity of 130 โ 135 beds due to COVID-19 virus transmission safety 
10  protocols.  
11  29.  One of the two shelters is the Torres Community Shelter, a year-round congregate 
12  emergency shelter that is available to unsheltered men and women. It also operates a shelter in 
13  another location for families with children. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Torres Shelter 
14  currently has a reduced capacity of 120 beds.  
15  30.  Guests of the Torres Shelter sleep in a communal setting and are provided meals.  
16  The shelter has limited ability to provide accommodations for guests with disabilities or medical 
17  conditions who require a special diet, private space or service animals. For the most part, the 
18  shelter cannot accommodate pets.  
19  31.  The second shelter, Safe Space Winter Shelter, is a temporary winter shelter. 
20  However, it did not open in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. In February 2021, the shelter 
21  opened a medical referral-only shelter in rotating locations with 10 to 15 beds for unsheltered 
22  individuals, including those discharged from Enloe Hospital or Oroville Hospital or referred by 
23  Project Roomkey. The Safe Space Winter Shelter will end in mid-April 2021. The shelter is 
24  currently full and has a waitlist. It is not generally available to people who are unsheltered. 
25  32.  Project Roomkey provides hotel rooms to unhoused people who are vulnerable to 
26  complications from COVID-19, in accordance with Center for Disease Control (CDC) Guidelines 
27  to provide non-congregate sheltering wherever possible and with state and local shelter-in-place
